column4: Perhaps someone here could tell me, how does one bring up a list of the wifi signals found?
- sudo iwlist wlan0 scan
- gksudo network-manager    I believe
that isn't on the new desktop without starting it from the commandline?
- ALT F2
- sudo iwconfig... what is the name of your wireless interface?
is that 'wifi0' ?
- most likely... sudo iwlist wifi0 scan
jrib doing sudo iwconfig actually is showing the ESSID I expected to see in a list of potential ESSIDs
that did it. You are quite good.
:P
I'm surprised that there is no gui app by default on the desktop for doing that though.
- there should be... network-manager pops up on my laptop install (I turned it off on my desktop though)
network-manager does have an icon in my system tray but it seems to have no content in it.
- System -> Preferences -> Sessions -> add network-manager to your startup list
everything is greyed out except for VPN Connections >
- if you right-click on it you may have to choose Enable networking
- it shows them for me... if you walk around, based on the beacon timing of each router, it will update.
What do you click on to get the list of avaliable networks?
- ask jrib... I dont use that except on my laptop which I barely bootup anymore.
- I think I might know the problem... if you got your wireless device working via        sudo iwconfig you may need to sudo ifconfig wifi0 down     then re-enable it via nm-applet so it "has control"

my guess is that the same reason "sudo iwlist wifi0 scan" works and "sudo iwlist wlan0 scan" does not, is the same reason that there is no list of available networks showing up in the nm-applet. Maybe there is some way to tell nm-applet to scan using wifi0 too.
- maybe so... perhaps you can pass it parameters when you launch it?  man nm-applet ?
